reviewText: Unfortunately, this movie was poorly cast. The storyline is there, the idea is exciting and genuinely romantic. The cast, principals in particular is really off. there is no chemistry between Gerrard Butler and Hilary Swank. It comes down to Hilary Swank's inability to be a romantic leading lady. It's hard to imagine her romantically with anyone and Gerard Butler doesn't come through for both of them. Harry Connick Jr., who used to be a gorgeous crooner, from Hope Floats to a reoccurring role on Will and Grace has now turned into an overweight guy who is getting second-hand roles. Gina Gershon, who is usually great in each of her performances, is plagued by bad face impressions. James Marsters is extremely underused. Lisa Kudrow, the comedic light of the film, shows promise but could be a lot funnier and is generally a lot funnier in all her other roles. The only interaction that makes sense is that between Kathy Bates' character and Hilary Swank's. Their mother-daughter relationship is shaky but gets the much-needed boost at the end. The admirable features of the movie are all due to what must be genuinely good source material, i.e. the novel it is based on. The idea that the heroine isn't dependant on the guy for her salvation, but, in fact, looses herself in him is gutsy. The fact that her involvement with the love of her life stunts her ability to find herself and that it's his death that releases her is so fascinating to see on the screen and so real, that's it's scary. I only wished they would focus more on this and develop it. If they had only embraced it! Still, as far as romantic comedies go, it's refreshing to see that every once in a while there comes a movie that doesn't end with a happily ever union.

I know the movie didn't get rave reviews from the critics but who cares.  There are lots of movies that are considered bad yet we love them. Such was the case with this one. I thought the entire cast was magnificent. Each was so unique and you'd never think they were the best of friends and yet they were. I had to buy another one due to just wearing the first one out. So the haters can hate it but for those of us who loved it, well we will continue to love it.

The movie was actually pretty good. I didn't like the character of Holly though. She seemed flaky, selfish and flighty. Everything had to revolve around her. In the beginning it's starts with a fight between the couple of Holly and her husband Gerry. She has no idea what she wants and she can't keep a job, quit 5 because she couldn't work for idiots, and just started getting a regular paycheck on the sixth job. She then complained about money yet she doesn't mind spending money on designer clothing, her excuse is she buys them on eBay. So I guess that makes the money she spends on them not count. She doesn't want a baby her excuse being their living situation. She talks on and on about showing people houses that she can't afford. What exactly does she expect to happen? If money is the problem, why not buy clothes and shoes like a regular person instead of needing designer everything? eBay does count. Gerry even offered to get a second job if that's what she wanted. He's all about trying to give his wife what she wants, she has no idea what that is! Holly is very selfish, everything is always about her wants and needs and her husband is expected to just agree and go along. When he dies, it's still all about her. Her grief over losing someone it looks like she hadn't appreciated anyway. Someone who took the time to try to help her through her grief. He's kind enough to write her letters written to ease her through it starting on her 30th birthday. As she goes along her friends are surrounding her. Yet towards the end when one of her friends is getting married, she can't even be happy for her. She starts avoiding her friends, no calls, no nothing. All of a sudden she decides to design shoes. And finally she seems to be able to focus on someone other than herself. She decides to see her friend at her bridal fitting to apologize and ask to design her wedding shoes. Apparently sometime after that she falls for someone else and lives happily ever after. I like the movie but it would've been nice if the focus wasn't about her wants and needs all throughout the movie.

I didn't read the book, so I'm only rating the movie... although, I might pick up the book one day to see what all the hubbub is about.  The screenplay was fairly good with two exceptions: (a) the sex scene in Ireland seemed out of character/unnecessary and (b) the relationship between Hilary Swank's grieving widow and Harry Connick's lovesick bartender really missed.  Gerard Butler turned in a solid performance (the occasional slip in his faux-Irish brogue didn't bother me too much) and Kathy Bates stole a couple of scenes, as you would expect.  Also good supporting turns by Gina Gershon, Lisa Kudrow and James Marsters.  Harry Connick, Jr. (who I normally like) had a purposefully unsympathetic role which was poorly written - I thought he was wasted in this film.  Incredible camera work for all the scenes filmed in Ireland.

As others have noted, Hillary Swank can be great in certain vehicles, but totally miss in others.  This movie falls toward the later for me: she's not terrible, but I never empathized with her character (she comes across as spoiled and entitled here) and I could envision other actresses who would be more engaging in the role.

At 2 hours, I thought the movie could have been more concise without sacrificing the story line... but that's what happens when the director is also the screenwriter.  All-in-all, I thought the movie was well crafted and IMDb's rating of 7.1/10 is spot on.

How do I love thee? Let me count the ways lol. I love how you meet Gerry and Holly in the beginning a real couple having a fight that a million couples (the one I'm in included) about if they are ready or not ready to have a baby and her fear because of her own father issuses (which I can also understand). But then when she loses him anyway it's heartbreaking and a part of me felt it was kind of mean like let the woman move on but he knew better then anyone what she would really need to move on. It sounds weird but she almost needed his permission and his guidence to move on. I also really liked Holly's best friends in the movie and how hard it can feel when it looks like everyone is moving on with their wonderful carefree lives and you're just depressed and not moving at all. It's really about not loving the man you were with anymore but loving him but know you need to move on and if the man you loved really loved you he wouldn't want you to just be a person who walks and talks like their alive but really are alive. Because if something happened to me and Joe stopped his life right then and there and just lived sad and alone for the rest of his life I'd be mad at him because he's amazing and while I might hate him with another girl I'd be a much happier dead person knowing he's with someone who he loves and who loves him back then is all alone. That is what loving someone means, wanting them to be happy even if it isn't with you. Thats what I took from this movie anyway. But best quote I've gotta say is Lisa Kudrow when Gina Gerswhen's husband says "this is why you can't get a guy." and Lisa's character let's him in on a BIG point in what it means to becoming equal to men in this world trust me.  Snuggle up with your man or your big strong dog or even your big handsome teddy bear, a box of tissues and make sure to take off your eye make up not actually just all make up so you don't have to wash your face 10 times and your pillow case is ruined lol.

Notice: my viewing experience may be unique due to the circumstance accompanying it.

First of all, do NOT attempt to watch this if you are streaming it via Comcast. The movie started decently, following the clich chick-flick format that has been squeezed so hard, all that's left is a thick, pulpy orange juice that's difficult to swallow. But Gerard is a man's man (see 300) and Hilary Swank is the type of girl you could take home to mom if she doesn't punch your lights out first.

We are acquainted with these two in the first scene, as they argue over a seemingly over-dramatic issue that fits the aforementioned format all too well. Of course, the end up reconciling over a passionate kiss that left me wondering if the two had practiced off screen. Naturally, my thoughts gravitated towards how much "practicing" this line of work typically entails. Maybe I should be an actor?

Note: this is where I dozed off for approximately 15 minutes.

I awoke to my girlfriend sobbing hysterically at the streaming wheel of death taunting her as Comcast yet again fails to meet basic customer expectations. Knowing full well my domestic responsibilities, I grumble as I pick up my phone to prepare to ream some poor, minimum wage sap who's only means of earning a living revolves around taking a verbal crucifixion over something he has no control over. All the while, Comcast executives laugh manically over our mutual misfortune, in some lush office on the top floor of the biggest skyscraper that can be found in the 7th layer of hell.

Before I can hit the speed dial, my girlfriend is trying to fill the short moments between her gasps for air with an explanation of her discomfort. SPOILER ALERT: Gerard dies. Not only has he died, but he tortures Hilary by sending her letters from beyond the grave in apparent attempt to prove once and for all that life still sucks after death. Of course girls will eat this sh*t up, but if you are a heterosexual male with a disdain for overly dramatic plot lines, don't watch this movie. Especially via Comcast streaming.

I sat through this film but it took two evenings and I fast-forwarded the part in Ireland, on the second sitting.  I'm not sure why I didn't like it more than I did.  The story is interesting enough and the whole cast is excellent.  I think the casting is the problem.  Hillary Swank is a talented actress but I think rom-com's may not be what she does best.  She has great emotional depth and here she's supposed to play cute and frothy.  Actually there's nothing wrong with her performance; it's just that it belongs in a totally different film, not one where her pals are Lisa Kudrow and the other buddy.  She does tragedy well; comedy not so much.  There are a number of other Hollywood actresses who could have polished off this role with great aplomb and made into a shining little bauble.  I think the director couldn't decide to go for funny or pathos and the result is this mess.  There's very little chemistry between her and Butler and although the film makes it plain that he loves her, it doesn't show us why.  She seems uptight and cranky and although she has a lovely body the terrible plaid dresses she wears do nothing for her.

Gerard Butler is always charming, Kathy Bates does a good job as the long suffering Mom, Lisa Kudrow is always fun to watch, and the fellow who plays the Irish friend of the deceased Gerry is beyond adorable!  I found the character played by Harry Connick Jr. quite problemmatic.  I don't want to give away any of the plot, only will say that his characterization seemed to leave a bad taste in my mouth.

I think the film could have been a lot better with the single change of the leading actress.  It's not bad, just doesn't have that fun and sparkle that rom-coms are supposed to have.

Richard LaGravanese (The Fisher King, Freedom Writers) takes you on a delicate and poignant ride of heartbreak and mourning.  Known for being somewhat sentimental, LaGravanese paints another powerful story of how love sadly parted by chance, can still be celebrated, appreciated and survived.  What some men might call another "chick flick" is really a heart-wrenching journey into the common emotions we all share surrounding the death of cherished love.  It is impossible to not enjoy Gerard Butler as the Irish bon vivant who sweeps the audience off its feet much like he does the uncertain and self-constrained Hillary Swank.  Even further stealing the show is Harry Connick, Jr., the mildly depressed and socially awkward bartender with no filter, who says everything confused men want to say to women they admire and gets away with it.  Bonus appearances from the always strong Kathy Bates and wonderfully scattered Lisa Kudrow add more flavor, and along with the steady James Marsters and reliable Gina Gershon, P.S. I Love You isn't your average romantic comedy.  It's a powerful story of mourning and rebirth, and at its core, what life is all about.

Just finished watching this movie and was not disappointed.  Gerard was great as usual, the good caring man who goes the extra mile in showing his love for his wife.  Hillery was very good as were all the others, Harry, Lisa, and Kathy.  I did not know the others but all were very good.  Do need some tissues near by, but there are a lot of laughs also.  Many very poignant moments caught let me just say real life.  I understand from some postings that it was a disappointment to those who read the book; however, I think the real point of this movie was the love shown by Gerard's character Gerry for his wife and no matter how much it might have deviated from the book the point was made of what he did.  It stands as a lasting memorial to the great love and compassion Gerry had for his wife and we can all learn some valuable lessons from this movie.

I don't recall too many, if any, romantic comedies on Hillary Swank's resume.  In fact, I don't recall too many comedies on her resume.  But, in a film where she doesn't die by the end, Swank shines as always as she plays a woman who, in the wake of her beloved husband's sudden death, must learn to pick up the pieces and move on in her life.  As I've said, Swank did as great as ever here and this change of genre was surprising but ultimately welcome.  Did anyone beside me see Phoebe from "Friends?  Yes, I know Lisa Kudrow was in the movie, but unfortunately, she's Phoebe.  So seeing her as a female version of Joey was just weird...and sometimes a bit forced.  But she and the rest of the cast were still pretty good throughout the film.  Even Harry Connick, Jr. showed some life here and there.  And Gerard Butler left us with a memorable performance as Swank's now-dead husband, making us miss him all the more.  My only wish is that we'd seen more of Kathy Bates on the grounds that she's just awesome.  My biggest praise goes for the ending as it did not go the way we all thought it would.  Oh, there were plenty of hints towards the ending every one of these movies moves towards, but there's a nice, and completely believable, twist at the end that leaves us with as much, if not a bit more, satisfaction as if a stereotypical ending had been chosen.  This is a fine film.  Enjoy.  P.S.:  I love you, film.

This movie features a really charming Gerard Butler and a very vulnerable Hillary Swank.  It is sweet and romantic and sad and funny at the same time.  And the character of William (Gerry's Irish bandmate) is  wonderfully sensitive and endearing.  It can be a very difficult movie to watch if you have experienced this type of loss, so be forewarned.  I do not think it will make cinematic history but it is very touching and I enjoyed it.  Will watch it again someday, but not now.

I love this movie it hit home to me . I lost the love of my life to illness in a blink of an eye and when that kind of pain happens it crushes you. My love was a Irish as well and a lot like the character Gerry loved the limelight and was funny, loved family, friends, and parties. So even when there were times when I knew Holly"s pain and it was hard to watch at certain points. It was also a comforting movie to me. It made think of the happy times we had together and realize we all go through grief like this at some point. It is what we do with that grief do we let it consume us or try to move forward as best we can. It is what that lost loved one would want you to do.

This movie is one of the only chick flicks I actually enjoy watching.

Listen to me:  If you saw it and didn't like it, try it again.  Bet you would like it--there's a lot going on that you might not catch the first time around.  Some movies are like that. Personally I would not buy/rent this or any other romance movie (if it wasn't for my gf) but she sits through my Action movies so I would gladly do the same for her.... bottom line its a chick flick, but its a watchable chick flick.

This is a very brief review - more to follow later.

I struggled through watching this film to completion - first on an airplane on my Nook HD+ tablet and then in bed on the Nook at home.

The very first part of the film that I found irritating was how a very critical event in the plot was handled.  I don't want to provide a spoiler, but suffice it to say that some major events happened within the first few minutes very abruptly.

Hilary Swank as the lead is a less than appealing character.  Gerard Butler makes for great "eye candy".  The other characters were never developed, so there were many vague, boring and tedious aspects to the film.  I did not find Harry Connick, Jr. intriguing in his role at all.  The camerawork also did not shed an attractive light on Hilary Swank, either.  Her face looked very "horse-y" throughout much of the film.
Its an epically beautiful love story that belongs in every movie collection . Pure emotion within the first few minutes of starting .

This was a very heart warming and intriguing movie.  I really liked how the story unfolded. It kept me interested throughout the entire movie wondering how each letter would be delivered and what the letter would say to do.
The plot was surprisingly good and Gerard Butler was so freaking AMAZING! I have never watched a love story quite like this one...LOVED IT!

This is a really good movie and is perfect for a romantic evening.  It makes one laugh and cry, sometimes at the same time.  I would highly recommend it.

Annie H.

Here's my last email to the vendor. I think it sums up my experience:

You obviously didn't read my email. I have no intention of returning the DVD as it is not worth the effort to send back a $7 DVD (that's what I paid including shipping) for which I'm going to pay at least half that much in shipping. Not to mention the time and aggravation just to get it shipped. And by the way, I find your statement about it clearly stating Region 2 in the description to be frustrating. How would you expect the average consumer to know what that means. I'm a US customer purchasing a DVD from a US based company. It seems to me that your system would be sophisticated enough to recognize that. For that matter, Amazon should never have recommended the item to me in the first place knowing that I live in the US.

A widow follows a trail of letters from her dead husband, who is trying to help her move on with her life from beyond the grave. My wife was bawling over this movie. I didn't cry - cause I'm too manly - and I thought it got kind of sappy. The portrayal of a widow who can't move on from her husband's death felt real, though. I can totally see myself that way if my wife died. The ending was a nice twist on the romcom genre, and the whole thing felt better than average. Worth seeing.
Despite not being a fan of "chick flicks" I tried to keep an open mind.  This movie was just flat boring and dull.  Gerard Butler should be slapped.
From the first 5 minutes of the movie I cried, laughed, cried. I have to say it was one of the best chic flix I have ever watched!!!

I've seen this movie multiple times now. When I think about it, I don't remember how funny it is and think of it as boring, but when I watch it again, it's fun and funny at times. I highly recommend for anyone who likes a good romantic comedy.

I guess it must just be me, judging from the other reviews, but I found this movie extremely depressing.  I cried through much of it.  In the beginning, I felt bad for Gerard Butler's character who was engaging and adorable but who had to deal with a bitchy, self-centered, unreasonable wife.  Then for the rest of the movie the grief process was so painful to watch.  Anyone that has suffered through a painful loss in the past will identify with the wife's pain.  The efforts of friends and family to help were relatively useless and not that enjoyable to watch either.  I disliked the twist at the end, and the assumption that William was the guy for her because he had a nice body was sort of disgusting.  Here she had just gone through a profound grief experience and she is supposed to be all happy again because she falls into bed with a nice-looking guy.  Please.  Gerard Butler was the real star of the movie, and his role in the film was minimal.  I would not recommend it unless you are eager to experience suffering along with the Hilary Swank character and watch scene after scene of her selfish, obnoxious behavior.
Must have been poorly made as if failed to keep running before movie was over.  We had to buy it from online in order to see the end.

I gave this movie the highest rating you had . I absolutly love this movie its funny its sad its every thing you could want in a good movie I truly wish they would make second movie. No matter how many times I watch it I never get tired of it

This is added to my crazy movie selection. thank you, I really love this movie and it's nice to be able to watch it whenever I want.

I watched this one more out of curiosity, not knowing much what it was about.  And I was shocked at how much I liked it.

The cast was outstanding, even the ones I normally don't care much for.  Everyone brought a sincerity to their characters that really showed through.  It's a slow movie, but it's never boring or dull.  Every moment has something that contributes to the whole, and regardless of your situation in life, it's full of moments that you can relate to.

It *is* a sad movie - you can't help but sympathize with the main character, and even as a guy, there's plenty of times the eyes water up.  But there's some shockingly sudden hilarious moments that will have you bark out loud with laughter, totally unexpectedly.

The journey she takes in healing after her husband's death is so well portrayed.

Great movie, and if you're a guy with a significant other, it's one you can score bonus points for renting, and you may just find that you enjoy yourself as well.

Although I fell in love with the cast as soon as it started! I can honestly say there wasn't 1 moment that I just wished "Is it over yet?" I really don't go 4 chick flicks. Although, I've gotta say that I am glad that I did actually checked this 1 out! I wasn't real sure about "the energy" between those 2-really,not that I don't like Hillary Swank! This movie is a real tearjerker. I liked the plot very much. It deals with grief and how society or family expects young widowed people to deal with the grief. It also deals with guilt and regret: the thing we wish we would have done or said to our loved ones before their tragic and untimely death. It is a film that makes you think about your loved ones, about not taking them for granted. It is a beautiful movies. I wish I had discovered this movie before I became widowed at a young age.

----Larry

A wonderful love story, sprinkled with self fulfillment. The movie not only focuses on romantic love, but also on motherly, sisterly love as well as friendship.  Funny, touching, a little gem with great actors..  Especially Hillary Swank.  Carpe diem and carpe the ones you love.

A friend highly recommended this film, and with nearly five stars, I thought - why not? I didn't actually read the reviews, but maybe I should have. It might have prepared me for the emotional tug-of-war that was about to ensue.

This is definitely one of those movies that reminds you of your own humanity. If you haven't cried in a while and wonder if it's even possible to cry, watch this. You'll be surprised at how easily you connect to the characters (and, therefore, crumble with them) as they move through the various stages of grief from different perspectives (first person as the heroine herself, or third person as her family/friends/neighbors).

If you've ever been in one of these positions, you'll understand why this film got such great reviews. It's not a feel-good make-you-happy film, it's a reminder that life is precious, and we're all in this together. Enjoy it, the message is priceless.
IM GIVING IT 5 STARS BECAUSE THIS IS MY BABES, FAVORITE LOVE STORY..... SO, THIS WILL BE ONE OF HIS MANY EXTRA SPECIAL CHRISTMAS GIFTS 2012....

this is a great movie and so worth watching with your significant other!!!! Hillary is amazing! And the friendships between the 3 women characters are very seet and very real

This is a sweet story about love that transcends death. Hillary Swank is her usual terrific self and her GFs Gina Gershon and Lisa Kudrow are very complementary to her character. Kathy Bates and Harry Connick Jr are terrific support. Gerard Butler is, well, Gerard Butler. He's got great comic timing and is, of course, adorable.
This is an amazing love story. It is very sad, but the adventure makes you smile. I bawl my eyes out every time I watch it. Great movie! such a neat story.
Love Love Love this movie. One of my all-time favorites. It is such a well written film and a beautiful love story.
One of my all time favorite movies.  A true love story.  It sucks you in and by the end after all the tears you have a smile on your face.
I love this movie and I usually do not like romance movies.  So funny and sweet and Gerard Butler is not bad either!

Just a beautifully presented movie of a very sad experience of a young woman.  Having experienced a similar loss of my wonderful husband, I could identify with her emotions.  I thought that it was very well done.

I'm not the greatest movie reviewer.  I'll be honest about that up front.  I tend to watch movies purely for my enjoyment and will usually rate it based on that alone.  I rarely judge the acting, the script, the development of plot, etc.  I really enjoyed watching this movie because it had "a little of everything"--something I personally need in a movie.  It made me laugh and cry.  It had seriousness and lightheartedness. The only disconnect I had was at the beginning of the movie.  The plot seemed to make a jump and I was left with a few questions.  I wondered if I missed something in the first 20 minutes of the movie.  Overall, though, it was a movie that I'd watch again and recommend to my girlfriends.  Not sure if it'd be a movie my hubby would watch with me, though.
I had already seen this movie prior to purchase. If you enjoy romantic movies this is a great one, a bit sad, but well worth watching.
After I lost my boyfriend, I received lots of signs he was still with me..... I never saw him however, a friend saw this and recommended I see it. OMG I cried and cried, what perfect timing!

P.S. I Love You is a good and well-thought out movie. I've never been a huge fan of Hilary Swank but I really enjoy her performance as recent widow, Holly. A lot of romantic comedies are pretty predictable but not this one. It has a happy beginning, a sad middle, and a hopeful ending. My only gripe with this movie is Harry Connick Jr. Seems like he is always being the jerk. I just can't relate to him and he tends to overact. P.S. I Love You will leave you pleasantly surprised, definitely one to watch!
Instant classic that didn't get near enough attention when it was released. Highly recommend for any man, woman, couple, young or old. Very well done, very well written.
Really a good movie, wish I could be so creative when my time comes. A must see with your girl

Great movie...saw it on TV and just had to buy it. It's a love story, a comedy, a tear jerker and hopeful. Loved the characters,and the actors where great...twists and turns. Makes one hopeful that love is always there in some shape or form.  Hope you enjoy it as much as I did.
I was very pleased. The disk was in great shape and the cover was in good shape. I could read the cover.
This one may have a sad base, but the story told is an enjoyable tear-jerker.  Have a box of kleenex next to you and enjoy!

always loved Judy but when I saw her sing in kinda tandem with Hillary to parallel a deep loss of love it spoke to me like never before, what a powerful performance!!!  I know this is about Gerry n Holly but everyone else makes do with their incisive comments... I found Gerry to be resurrected to walking on water, EVERY single scene with him looking so loving, handsome, and most of all seXy....  who is married after 10yrs in NYC and sees every memory sooooo saccarine syrupy overkill... we get it, Butler looks better than he did in his first foray well over 15yrs ago... thought Mom was too bitter in the you will always be alone and this memorial project was a waste, geez, thanks for the support in only her FIRST year of grieving, glad she got over her absolute love of her life in less than a year, bravo! and seems like the only thing they all do is go out and party, guess to show off her shoes???  Marie Antoinette did the same thing with less spectacular results, but hey this is 2008, so when someone has their health, a good business, friends and close relationship with her daughter I am sposed to just fall to pieces when she can't have everything?? ack.... Secondly, if you know you don't like Swank or Butler - then just don't watch the movie to begin with, but don't watch it and then complain about how much you can't stand to watch them. This is a great movie - people are so used to the ending that they expect (ie Swank ending up with Connick) that they can't appreciate a movie that deviates from thier expectations. I didn't see that they had any chemistry to begin with anyway. I love him as a musician and actor, but thier characters had no spark together and this was apparent from the beginning, it was right that they didn't end up together. Jeffrey Dean Morgan is adorable, him and Swank go great together. I also find it funny that people will complain about how this movie "wasted thier time" etc, if so - why write a 3 page review about it? Isn't that wasting more time? Move on.

Love this movie. One of the few I could watch over and over. Kind of like re-reading favorite parts of  "The Princess Bride" by William Goldman, and still smiling and finding it humorous. When you love something, you want to experience it again and again. Perhaps I love it because I've lost so many loved ones in the past seven years, and this movie is all about love and loss and dealing with life when you just don't think you can get out of bed. It's a story of a flawed woman who despite her flaws, is truly loved. About a man who reaches beyond the grave and helps her to deal with life again.

There's realism to this movie--not just a smooth, easily flowing, wrap it all up by the end type of movie, although there is a bit of that too. This one is somewhat messy and disjointed along the way. Again, just like real life. Ups, downs, laughter, crying, some weirdness thrown in. Unexpected in places, awkward in others. If you've lost someone you love, this movie carries you along, and leaves you in a better place mentally and emotionally than where you started. How many movies do that?

Usually I can't stand movies of this sort ("The Notebook", "A Walk in the Clouds", etc.), but I must say I was pleasantly surprised after watching this film.

A friend of mine brought it to my home one evening for a girl-talk + manicure session, and an inner part of me groaned...

"Oh no -- here comes cheesiness..."

I felt guilty for looking down on this movie before even watching it, because after thoroughly enjoying it I realized how wrong a person can be when he or she jumps to naive conclusions.

Is this story cheesy? In many ways, yes. Movies of this sort usually are.

BUT -- the reason why this movie overcomes its groan factor is because Hillary Swank and Gerard Butler are so believable. I didn't think they'd have much chemistry, but they make the story work.

I won't ruin the movie for you, but it's a cute story that leaves one with pangs of longing for something beautifully similar to happen to herself.

`P.S. I Love You' is a strange film in that it manages to be both funny and sad at the same time.

When Holly loses her husband, Gerry, to a brain tumour she really struggles to come to terms with her loss.  Then on her 30th birthday she receives the first of many letters from Gerry that he wrote before he died.  These comfort and guide her through her grief and set her back on the path of her life again.

This film has some genuinely funny moments, some of which come from Lisa Kudrow, and one minute you will be feeling choked up from a particular scene, only to be laughing in the next.  Swank is ok as Holly and Gerard Butler is good as Gerry, but I have to say one of the stronger performances comes from Kathy Bates, which is no surprise whatsoever as she always is a class actress.

This has some wonderful flash backs of Holly and Gerry's early relationship and some of the surprise's he springs on her in the letters are poignant and heartfelt.  This is a bit of a `chick flick' (which is no criticism, more an observation), but it is done very well and despite being a little over-long, it is a touching enough film with an original storyline to keep you interested.  Some parts of this film are superfluous (like Harry Connick Jr's character who could easily be cut with no loss to the film), but I guess they add an extra dimension that would otherwise be lacking.

All in all this is an engaging and reasonably emotional film and it's gentleness is offset by it's humour, which makes for an entertaining combination.  This is worth a viewing at some point and makes a nice way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.

When Gerry (Gerard Butler) finds out he doesn't have much time left to live, he plans a sort of scavenger hunt for his beloved wife Holly (Hilary Swank). A few weeks after he passes away, Holly gets the first surprise in the mail, and each surprise leads to another letter from her deceased husband. Some of Gerry's messages force her to go out and spend time with her friends, thereby taking her out of mourning and letting her enjoy everything beautiful about life that she had forgotten about.

Indeed, I thought it was a beautiful story. I know some reviewers said it was very predictable, and while you do get the idea that Holly is slowly moving on to bigger and better things, the story is not that obvious otherwise. At times, Holly feels like relapsing and going back to depression; at other times, we find out a surprise about herself or one of her friends. People who love romantic comedies will find this movie adorable; people who do not will still find it bearable.

And the concept behind what Gerry did is great too. Surprises for a sad person can be helpful in lifting them up. And while you shouldn't cling on to the past too tightly, letters from a loved one who is gone are a wonderful keepsake to remember them.

I search for movies I can watch with my teen children and the reviews indicated this would be allright.  What they didn't say was that Harry Connick's character talked about using prostitutes, and having two ex-girlfriends who are now in a relationship with each other.  In an odd twist, Swank's character (while receiving letters from her deceased husband) has a one-night stand with a man she's just met.  Please!  After being married to Gerard Butler?  Kathy Bates (mom) could have added a badly-needed element of depth to show Swank's journey through grief.  Lisa Kudrow, as Hilary's pal, was a shallow one-dimensional character who was ruthlessly looking for a man to marry - another misfire which could have been developed to add depth and contrast to Swank's grieving process if her character had been better developed. There were touching moments between Butler and Swank, and it was a great cast and concept, but the tacky elements left a bad taste.

This is a truly enjoyable movie if you are a sucker for a good romance story like I am. The story is really about true love and how it can continue on after death. It is also a story of a husband who over time gives his surviving wife the ability to move on with her life as she is currently familiar with. There are moments when I wanted to cry, laugh, and just think about the story of this movie and imagine that something like this really could happen. The movie at times leave you anxious  during the middle part of the movie but aren't unexpected movie endings something all viewers crave? You will get that and more in P.S. I love you. After I watched I thought this is a 3 star movie but thinking about it a day later I realized there are not many films out there that can grab every sense of emotion you have and pull you along for the ride. So it is a post movie 5 star rating. Enjoy P.S. I love you is a very good movie. Though the movie starts out in a long argument followed by complete confusion if you haven't read a review it tackles and tugs on every emotion a movie goer should have for this type of film. From a males perspective, it was a little tough to get into at first but the movie grows on you as it continues.

**1/2

Before he dies, Gerry Kennedy (Gerard Butler) - the pluckiest victim of a brain tumor since the stiff-upper-lipped Bette Davis faced-down a similar fate in "Dark Victory" - comes up with an ingenious way to continue giving Holly (Hilary Swank), his soon-to-be widow, advice from beyond the grave.  He composes a series of upbeat letters to be delivered to her at regular intervals after he`s gone - missives that contain specific instructions on how to pick up the pieces of her shattered world and move on with her life.  You see, Holly was kind of an uptight stick-in-the-mud when they were married, and now the too-good-to-be-true, happy-go-lucky Irishman wants to loosen her up by getting her to perform karaoke, sending her on an all-expenses-paid trip to the place of his birth, and encouraging her to become a cobbler (I kid you not).  But will Gerry's continued presence in his widow's life actually retard her ability to let go of the past and start anew?  And does this "Ghost" knockoff stand a ghost of a chance of becoming as universally beloved as that earlier husband-hanging-around-after-death romantic classic?

Beyond the cringe-inducing creepiness of its premise, "P.S. I Love You," based on the novel by Cecilia Ahern, is one of those annoying romantic comedies in which the women get all goofy, frisky and/or tongue-tied the moment some good-looking guy so much as steps into their line of vision.  Moreover, Gerry is portrayed as such a saintly figure, both before his demise and most definitely thereafter, that we never get to know him as a real, flesh-and-blood person in his own right; instead, in order to make all the ladies in the audience swoon over his magnificent romantic spirit - one, I might add, that no man in the real world has the slightest hope of ever living up to - writer/director Richard LaGravenese has seen fit to deprive Gerry of all those flaws each of us is entitled to just for being a member of the human race - and which are truly the only things that make a character interesting in the end.  And with that crucial dimension missing from the couple's relationship, we soon lose interest in Holly as well.  And, of course, the movie cheats by having Gerry's illness take place entirely off-camera, so as not to disturb the light romantic tone of the piece, but it does little to make us care about the couple.  The movie finally hits on some honest sentiment round about the 115-minute mark, and the story does avoid going down one painfully obvious narrative pathway towards the end, but, by that time, it's much too late to undo the damage.

A large cast of well-known and talented actors - Kathy Bates, Lisa Kudrow, Harry Connick Jr., among them - do yeomen work with poorly written parts, but it's an uphill slog against bathos, pratfalls and contrivance all the way.  Well, at least the Irish scenery is lovely.

Pass on Swank, although I realize the Director, and others, rule.  But horribly miscast. Pass on the script.  Pass on the direction.  The supporting cast was there, talented, and ready to work and they got the shaft.

I can hear the Director:  "Kathy, Lisa please be your sterotypes."
Please, actors:  save your money so that you can turn down wretched roles.

Apart from that, I am appalled that women reviewers like this film.  If you are really like this Holly character, then we're all doomed.
